thesis.description: In the fall of 1946 the author was assigned to the newly formed Experimental Surgical Laboratories of McGill University with the purpose of spending one year in investigative work, as a part of a graduate training program in surgery. Experimental surgery, as a branch of surgery, was at that time in its beginnings, both at McGill University and in other centers on this continent. It is, therefore, not surprising that several serious technical difficulties have prevented the completion of the proposed research at that time. The results of the investigation recorded in this thesis have been obtained during the session 1946-1947, and completed during the current session.
thesis.creator: Madore, Patrick.
thesis.subject: Experimental Surgery.
thesis.title: Experimental and Clinical Studies on the Pathogenesis of Non-Specific Mesenteric Lymphadenitis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Research with the domestic fowl has played an important part in the development of knowledge in fundamental endocrinology. The experiments of Hunter with domestic fowl in 1749 appear to constitute the first experimental demonstration of what would now be described as hormonal action by the gonad. Similarily, the experiments of Berthold in 1849 on the transplantation of fowl testes are regarded as the first demonstration of an endocrine secretion. [...]
thesis.creator: MacRae, Herbert Farquhar.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Chemistry.
thesis.title: Studies on the Estrogens of the Domestic Fowl.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The winter eggs of the phytophagous mite Panonychus ulmi (Koch) in Nova Scotia have been found to be killed by cold at the lower extremes of temperature. A more resistant form occurs in the colder areas of New Brunswick and Quebec. For short exposures the mean lethal temperature of overwintering eggs for the susceptible and resistant forms respectively is -24° F. and -35° F. [...]
thesis.creator: MacPhee, A.W.
thesis.subject: Entomology and Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Low Temperature Mortality of European Red Mite, Panonychus Ulmi (Kock), Winter Eggs and its Ecological Significance.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

degree.name: Doctor of Philosophy
degree.discipline: Department of Entomology and Plant Pathology

thesis.description: Emphasis on the chemistry of phosphorus in soils arises from its importance as a plant nutrient and from the influence which the chemical form of the element has upon its utilization by plants. The importance of phosphorus in plant nutrition is demonstrated by the fact that more than 4,000,000 tons of phosphatic fertilizers are used in Canada and the United States each year.
thesis.creator: MacLean, Angus Augustine.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Chemistry.
thesis.title: the Extraction, Isolation and Identification of Organic Phosphorus Compounds from a Podzol.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The Mount Reed quadrangle occupies 183 square miles in southern Quebec-Labrador. It is extensively covered by glacial drift and outwash with about 5 percent exposure. The ice sheet margin retreated northwards. The most extensive rock type is the biotite-quartz-oligoclase gneiss with garnetiferous and graphitic varieties. The gneiss consists of maficrich foliations of biotite and miner hornblende and felsicrich foliations of white quartz and oligoclase. [...]
thesis.creator: MacKean, B. E.
thesis.subject: Geological Science.
thesis.title: Geology of the Mount Reed Quadrangle Quebec
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The function of the thyroid gland has been studied in the experimental nephrotic syndrome. Significant urinary losses of hormonal iodine were found and were dependent on the degree of proteinuria. An increased release of thyroidal hormone appeared to compensate for the urinary losses of hormone. Thyroid function was judged adequate since peripheral utilization of hormone and the rate of oxygen consumption were unaltered in the nephrotic state.
thesis.creator: MacIntyre, William Cringan.
thesis.subject: Investigative Medicine.
thesis.title: Thyroid Function in Experimental Nephrosis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Two zoologists with considerable experience in the Canadian Arctic suggested to the writer that the "Gammarus Problem" would be an extremely interesting subject for investigation, and one which has several advantages, for material is relatively easy to obtain, and there are a number of species available.
thesis.creator: MacIntyre, R.J.
thesis.subject: Zoology.
thesis.title: Gammarus: some Aspects of the Genus with Particular Reference to Gammarus Oceanicus from Eastern Canada.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Religion has always played an important role in the life of the average Canadian community. This thesis is presented in the hope that something of the significance of one of the Churches may be seen in those districts that made up the Presbytery of Quebec of the Presbyterian Church in Canada for the years 1875-1925. It is a study not only in religious but also in social history, an attempt to see the life of the community as mirrored in one of the denominations. [...]
thesis.creator: MacDougall, Alexander Goodwill.
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: the Presbyterian Church in the Presbytery of Quebec 1875-1925.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis is, for a variety of reasons, both too short and too long. It is too short in that many subsidiary subjects - for example, the influence of Irish nationalism on Canadian development (a subject of absorbing interest to this Irish republican) - have had to be left untouched. Others, in addition, have had to be treated insufficiently. ln this category lie the question of Irish-French relations in Canada, which is only barely touched on, and the topic of education, especially the Irish contribution to the foundation of the system in Ontario, which gets only superficial examination.
thesis.creator: Lyne, Daniel Colman.
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: the Irish in the Province of Canada in the Decade Leading to Confederation.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Process control systems can in general be classified as closed-loop regulator systems which are subjected to both load and desired value changes. If such a system is conceived as a linear system then the loop gain will vary with changes in the process load. This results in the well known condition of unoptimization of the process response. [...]
thesis.creator: Lyle, Seaforth M.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: Closed Loop Optimization through Valve Characterization Techniques.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The Code of Manu is one of the most important the field of Indian Ethics which we possess. It marked an important innovation in the field of ethical literature, and it was written at a time when the old order had just passed away and a new one was beginning. But the new order was essentially conservative. The Code was an attempt to recreate a society embodying values which had developed well over half a millenium before the time of Manu. [...]
thesis.creator: Luck, David William.
thesis.subject: Comparitive Religion.
thesis.title: the Philosophical and Religious Context of the Laws of Manu.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis describes an exploratory investigation of the sorption of polymeric materials from solutions on to cellulose. A brief review of polymer sorption is given in Part I along with relevant comments on the swelling of cellulose. Parts II, III and IV have been prepared in a form suitable for publication in the scientific literature with little change. Each is complete in itself with its own introduction, experimental section, discussion and references.
thesis.creator: Luce, James E.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Sorption of Polymers on Celluloses.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Interest in the sulphur content of soils stems from the fact that sulphur is an element essential for the growth of all plants. As a result of the studies of various early workers (2, 9, 17, 24) on the nutrient requirements of crops, it was realized that sulphur was needed in amounts of the same order as phosphorus by most crops. However, it was concluded that all normal soils, assisted by other natural sources, were well able to supply crop needs, and no investigations were initiated at that period into the nature of sulphur in soils. [...]
thesis.creator: Lowe, Lawrence E.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: the Sulphur Status of Soils.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Absorption measurements, leading to the determination of the sensitivity of a paramagnetic resonance spectrometer, have been made at powers in the range 10-8 to 10-3 watt. Because of the nature of the measurements for which the instrument was intended, sensitivity is needed at both high and low powers. [...]
thesis.creator: Lortie, Helene.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Determination of the Sensitivity of a Paramagnetic Resonance Spectrometer.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This Thesis is primarily concerned with Water Intakes. These structures, which are an elementary part of any self-sufficient watersupply system, are necessary wherever the source of raw-water is a stream, river, lake or impounding reservoir. In comparison to the more complex units of a water-supply system, such as pumping stations and treatment plants, the water intake has been the subject of very little research. Even a summary reading of some of the published reference material on water intakes will serve to establish this statement. [...]
thesis.creator: Lindsay, Robert J.
thesis.subject: Civil Engineering.
thesis.title: the Details of Water Intakes - their Effect on the Turbidity of Water.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The various stages of development of electronic d.c. to a.c. parallel type inverters are reviewed, and the methods attempted by others in regulating the a.c. output voltage of such inverters are discussed.
thesis.creator: Liang, Kar K.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: an Electronic D.C. to A.C. Firing-Time-Controlled Inverter.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This work was undertaken at the suggestion of Dr. Bram Rose in an attempt to localize reagin in nasal polyps of patients with ragweed hay fever. Though there was much evidence suggesting that reagin must be bound in some way to skin and nasal mucus membrane (92, 94, 97), it had never been demonstrated directly. It was felt that the indirect fluorescent antibody technique of Coons (1) could be used profitably to reveal if and where reagin was localized.
thesis.creator: Leznoff, Arthur.
thesis.subject: Experimental Medicine.
thesis.title: the Use of the Fluorescent Antibody Technique for the Localization of Tissue Antigens.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Cavitation is a well known hydraulic phenomenon which may be associated with its destructive effects in hydraulic turbines and diesel cooling systems, although its advantages have been utilized in numerous ultrasonic devices such as flaw detectors, cleaning baths, and navigational echo-sounders. It should be emphasized that cavitation refers to the formation and collapse of vapour bubbles, while cavitation damage refers to the destruction of the guiding surface at the point of bubble collapse.
thesis.creator: Leith, William Cumming.
thesis.subject: Mechanical Engineering.
thesis.title: Cavitation Damage of Metals.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Housing patterns are considered significant not only because of a social feeling of identity but also because housing occupies more space than other building types, thus determining the resultant form of the community.
thesis.creator: Lehrman, Jonas B.
thesis.subject: Architecture.
thesis.title: Patterns in Housing Groups - Unity and the Inter-Relationship of Small-Scale Dwellings.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: At 100 miles range, radar can detect variations of 10^4 in rainfall intensity; the signals cover 64 db in power of which many radars can display less than 16 db at a time. Equipment has been designed and studied which displays successive factors of signal power, corrected in a known way for distance, as equally discernible steps of grey. One gain control adjusts the factors to display at a given time all or a chosen fraction of the 64 db. [...]
thesis.creator: Legg, Thomas H.
thesis.subject: Meteorology.
thesis.title: the Quantitative Display of Radar Weather Patterns on a Scale of Grey.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This project is concerned with the study of the phase behaviour in the image space of a microwave lens system suffering from aberrations. Three important types of primary aberrations have been investigated separately, spherical aberration, coma, and astigmatism. For this investigation, a program for the I.B.M. 650 digital computer was written to enable calculation of the Kirchhoff diffraction integral with any type of aberration.
thesis.creator: Lee, Lansun.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: Phase Distribution of Microwave Lenses with Aberrations.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The concept of antagonism has proved to be a fruitful approach in efforts to gather information on many physiological and pharmacological problems. In the case of the sympathetic system, ergot was used as early as 1906 by Dale, who then supplied an accurate description of what we know as 'adrenergic blockade'. This pharmacological effect may be defined as the blockade of responses to adrenaline, nor-adrenaline and other sympathomimetic amines and to sympathetic nerve activity. [...]
thesis.creator: Ledoux, G.
thesis.subject: Pharmacology.
thesis.title: On the Pharmacology of Phenoxybenzamine.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Scopulariopsis brevicaulis, a penicillium-like fungus, generally not considered pathogenic for human tissues has been occasionally isolated from cases of onychomycosis and from smooth skin lesions since the late 19th century. Isolates have been cultured on chunks of moist sterile calf hooves (Blank, 1951). An isolate has also been cultured in a distilled water medium containing glucose, salts and vitamins and containing particulate hoof keratin as sole source of nitrogen (Kapica and Blank, 1957). [...]
thesis.creator: Layne, Alice Edith Renate.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology and Immunology.
thesis.title: the Keratinolytic Activities of Scopulariopsis Brevicaulis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A preliminary investigation of the meteorological conditions on the Chamberlin Glacier in the summer of 1958 was carried out, with emphasis being placed on the measurement of some of the parameters needed to assess the energy balance of the glacier. The Expedition was not equipped with the instruments necessary to carry out a detailed micro climatological study, thus no quantitative measurements of heat balance were obtained. [...]
thesis.creator: Larsson, Peter.
thesis.subject: Geography.
thesis.title: Meteorological Observations on the Chamberlin Glacier; Brooks Range, Arctic Alaska, Summer 1958.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In recent years, the science of sociology has been increasingly directed towards the work that men do. Sociologists have studied many facets of this area of social behaviour and their insights and explanations add much to our knowledge of society. Through observing occupations, it is possible to learn about the world of work as a part of the social structure, and at the same time to gain understanding of the human beings who spend much of their lives in occupational milieux. [...]
thesis.creator: Lamb, Sylvia.
thesis.subject: Sociology.
thesis.title: the Scientist in Industry: a Study of an Occupational Career.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
